item.title: La crisis de Groenlandia deja lecciones para Europa
item.description: Tras una cumbre de emergencia, la presidenta de la Comisión Europea declaró que “la firmeza, el acercamiento, la preparación y la unidad” habían sido eficaces al lidiar con Estados Unidos.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger

media:content.media:credit: Juliette Pavy para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Una protesta contra el intento del presidente Trump de apoderarse de Groenlandia, en Nuuk, la semana pasada.

item.title: Premios Oscar 2026: las sorpresas y los desaires
item.description: Ariana Grande, Chase Infiniti y Paul Mescal quedaron fuera, pero los votantes hicieron sitio para Delroy Lindo, Kate Hudson y ‘F1’.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan

item.title: Why the Carney Fire Is Still Burning
item.description: The prime minister sees Trump all too well.
item.dc:creator: Ezra Klein
item.category: Trump: The Art of the Deal (Book)

media:content.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; source photograph by Christinne Muschi/Canadian Press, via Associated Press

item.title: It’s So Hard Not to Be Consumed by Rage
item.description: I worry that for some of us, our antipathy to Trump has become part of who we are, and it can be something of a personal poison.
item.dc:creator: Esau McCaulley

item.title: If You’re Marc Shaiman, for Every Plotz There’s a Zetz
item.description: Broadway, Hollywood and television have been kind to Marc Shaiman. But there’s a reason the subtitle of his new memoir is “Showbiz Stories From a Sore Winner.”
item.dc:creator: Jesse Green

media:content.media:credit: Amy Lombard for The New York Times

item.title: How the Composer Marc Shaiman Gave ‘Hairspray’ Its Beat
item.description: The award-winning composer and lyricist Marc Shaiman pulls back the curtain on the toe-tapping songs that helped turn “Hairspray” into a Broadway sensation.
item.dc:creator: Chevaz Clarke, Daniel Fetherston, Lauren Pruitt and Luke Piotrowski

item.title: Marc Shaiman on the Moments That Shaped His Career
item.description: Marc Shaiman revisits the high notes of his expansive career, and reflects on the moments and people that shaped him.
item.dc:creator: Chevaz Clarke, Daniel Fetherston, Lauren Pruitt and Luke Piotrowski

media:content.media:credit: Amy Lombard for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Bette Midler first met Shaiman when he was a teenager, and they have been friends and collaborators ever since.

item.title: Quote of the Day: Trump Pushes A.I. Data Centers, but One in Alabama Gets Cool Response
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, January 25, 2026.

item.title: The Podcaster Poking at France’s Biggest Secrets
item.description: Philippe Collin makes intricate series that are reshaping how French people understand uncomfortable parts of their history. Millions are tuning in.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter

media:content.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Philippe Collin, a journalist, author and podcaster, recording in Paris in November.

item.title: The Woman Who Stands Between Donald Trump and Greenland
item.description: Mette Frederiksen, Denmark’s leader, has taken big risks standing up to Mr. Trump. It might just be working — for now.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Maya Tekeli

media:content.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Denmark’s prime minister, Mette Frederiksen, in her office in Copenhagen.

item.title: Corrections: Jan. 25, 2026
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Jan. 25, 2026.

item.title: In Court Filings, Witnesses Describe Fatal Minneapolis Shooting of Alex Pretti
item.description: The filings raise further questions about the federal government’s narrative of what happened before federal agents shot Alex Jeffrey Pretti on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith

media:content.media:description: Federal agents in Minneapolis at the scene of the fatal shooting on Saturday.

item.title: Gun Activists Bridle at Suggestion That Pistol Justified Killing
item.description: The National Rifle Association and others have argued citizens need guns to fend off government. The killing of Alex Jeffrey Pretti, who carried a pistol, set off debate.
item.dc:creator: Danny Hakim and Thomas Gibbons-Neff

media:content.media:description: Federal officials released a photo of a gun they said the slain man had carried.

item.title: Timeline: How the Shooting of Alex Jeffrey Pretti Unfolded
item.description: A moment-by-moment analysis of video from the scene shows that Mr. Pretti was already restrained when fatal shots were fired, which appears to contradict the federal government’s account of the event.
item.dc:creator: Bora Erden, Devon Lum, Helmuth Rosales, Elena Shao and Haley Willis

item.title: William H. Foege, Key Figure in the Eradication of Smallpox, Dies at 89
item.description: His containment strategy helped wipe out the disease in the 1970s, one of the world’s greatest public health triumphs. He also led the C.D.C. and promoted childhood vaccination worldwide.
item.dc:creator: Keith Schneider and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

media:content.media:description: William H. Foege in 1985. He played a critical role in making smallpox the first infectious disease to be altogether eliminated. He stood beside a bust of Hygeia, the Greek goddess of health, at C.D.C. headquarters in Atlanta.

item.title: Read Bondi’s Letter to Minnesota’s Governor
item.description: Attorney General Pam Bondi sent a letter to Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota on Saturday that blamed him and other Democratic officials for allowing “lawlessness” in the state. It was not immediately clear if the letter had been sent before or after the fatal shooting of Alex Pretti.

item.title: State Terror Has Arrived
item.description: Minneapolis has made it plain.
item.dc:creator: M. Gessen

item.title: New York’s Latest Forecast Shows Heavy Snow, Then Sleet
item.description: The National Weather Service said Central Park could see up to a foot of snow by Monday.
item.dc:creator: Amy Graff

media:content.media:credit: Graham Dickie for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: New York City will see heavy snow at times when the storm moves into the region early Sunday.

item.title: Democrats Running for U.S. Senate in Texas Call for Overhaul of ICE
item.description: In a debate, Jasmine Crockett and James Talarico differed in their political styles but agreed that violent immigration agents needed to be held to account.
item.dc:creator: J. David Goodman

media:content.media:description: James Talarico, a state legislator, and U.S. Representative Jasmine Crockett are contending for the Democratic nomination in the Senate race in Texas.

item.title: Over a Thousand Protesters in NYC Denounce ICE After Latest Killing
item.description: The demonstrators braved frigid temperatures in Manhattan following the death of 37-year-old Alex Jeffrey Pretti in Minneapolis.
item.dc:creator: Nate Schweber

media:content.media:credit: Graham Dickie for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Attendees expressed a mix of anguished resignation and outraged optimism about what effect the demonstration might have.

item.title: ‘Dolly Plowton’ Debuts in Snowy Nashville
item.description: The new snowplow, named and painted to evoke a Tennessee heroine, is a symbol of how some Southern cities are trying to better prepare for winter storms.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane

media:content.media:credit: William DeShazer for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A new snowplow with an evocative name cleared snow for the first time from the streets of Nashville on Saturday.

item.title: Alert! Alert!
item.description: Mark MacLachlan’s latest puzzle has been thoroughly beta-tested.
item.dc:creator: Caitlin Lovinger

media:content.media:description: An example of the original computer bug: a moth, this one with glowing eyes, at an exhibition at the National Museum of Nature and Science in Tokyo.

item.title: Appeals Court Rejects Justice Dept. Push for Arrest Warrant for Don Lemon
item.description: The department had made an extraordinary request for the appeals court to force a judge to issue warrants for Mr. Lemon and four other people in connection with a church protest in Minneapolis.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer

media:content.media:description: A federal magistrate judge had refused to issue arrest warrants for the journalist Don Lemon and four other people the Trump administration was trying to charge.

item.title: Alex Jeffrey Pretti Knew He Wanted to Help Others
item.description: Shot and killed by immigration agents on a Minneapolis street, he wanted to be a ‘force of good in the world.’
item.dc:creator: Corina Knoll, Julie Bosman and Maia Coleman

media:content.media:description: Protests broke out in Minneapolis near the site where federal officials shot and killed Alex Jeffrey Pretti, a 37-year-old Minneapolis resident, on Saturday morning.

item.title: What We Know About a Second Fatal ICE Shooting in Minneapolis
item.description: Federal agents shot and killed a 37-year-old Minneapolis resident on Saturday, the city’s police chief said.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk

media:content.media:description: Federal agents confronting protesters after fatally shooting a 37-year-old Minneapolis man.

item.title: Pat Montandon, Socialite Who Sought Publicity, and Then World Peace, Dies at 96
item.description: She was known for her lavish parties and her marriage to one of the richest men in San Francisco. After he left her, she found a new purpose: visiting world leaders to plead for peace.
item.dc:creator: Penelope Green

media:content.media:description: Pat Montandon in 1981 with her boyfriend, James Borton, at Ronald Reagan’s inauguration.

item.title: Scenes From the Winter Storm
item.description: Images from across much of the country illuminate snow-covered streets and preparations for worse still to come.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

media:content.media:credit: Austin Anthony for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Snow in Bowling Green, Ky., on Saturday.

item.title: Democrats Vow Not to Fund ICE After Shooting, Imperiling Spending Deal
item.description: Key Senate Democrats said they would oppose legislation needed to avoid a government shutdown at the end of the week after federal agents shot and killed a Minneapolis resident.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson and Carl Hulse

media:content.media:description: Senator Mark Warner, Democrat of Virginia, wrote on social media that he would not vote to fund the Department of Homeland Security “while this administration continues these violent federal takeovers of our cities.”

item.title: Beatriz González, Who Chronicled Colombia’s Turmoil in Paint, Dies at 93
item.description: Often drawing from reproduced images or newspaper photos, she made work that quietly yet memorably critiqued her country’s social and political order.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter

media:content.media:description: The Colombian artist Beatriz González supervising the installation of an exhibition of her work at a gallery in Bogotá in 2019.

item.title: Trump Administration Tries to Shift Blame to Local Officials Over Shooting
item.description: Before an investigation could be conducted, they called Alex Jeffrey Pretti a “domestic terrorist” and said the governor and Minneapolis mayor were inciting rebellion.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers and Hamed Aleaziz

media:content.media:description: On social media, President Trump accused local officials, including Gov. Tim Walz and Jacob Frey, the mayor of Minneapolis, of “inciting Insurrection.”

item.title: Is Climate Change Weakening the Polar Vortex?
item.description: Rising Arctic temperatures and melting sea ice could be causing cold air to flow into the Northern Hemisphere. But not all scientists agree.
item.dc:creator: Eric Niiler

media:content.media:credit: Jalen Wright for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A study found that the stretching of the polar vortex was linked to increased severe winter weather in the United States in the past decade.

item.title: Agentes federales matan a un hombre de 37 años en Mineápolis
item.description: Dos semanas después de que un agente del ICE matara a Renee Good, los disparos provocaron una escalada de enfrentamientos entre las fuerzas del orden y los manifestantes.
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Londoño, Devon Lum, Hamed Aleaziz and Mitch Smith

item.title: Syria Announces Cease-Fire Extension, Hours After Truce With Kurds Expired
item.description: Syria’s government and Kurdish-led forces in the country’s northeast have clashed as President Ahmed al-Sharaa seeks to extend his authority across the entire country.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir

media:content.media:description: Kurdish-led militia fighters in northeastern Syria on Saturday. A cease-fire agreed upon with the government last Sunday called for the integration of Kurdish troops into the national army.

item.title: Ava DuVernay, Ethan Hawke and Patti LuPone Honor Robert Redford at Sundance
item.description: Film lovers celebrated the festival’s final year in Park City, Utah, with a surprise performance by Ms. LuPone.
item.dc:creator: Charlotte Dulany and Maggie Shannon

media:content.media:description: Ed Harris and Ethan Hawke

item.title: Millions of Gallons of Raw Sewage Spills Into the Potomac River
item.description: About 40 million gallons of untreated sewage a day has spilled into the river since a pipeline ruptured in Montgomery County, Md., on Monday, according to a utility company.
item.dc:creator: Mark Walker

media:content.media:description: Raw sewage flowing into the Potomac River in Maryland on Friday after a break in a major sewer line earlier in the week.

item.title: Frank Carone, a Brooklyn Power Broker, Is Under Federal Investigation
item.description: Federal prosecutors and the F.B.I. are scrutinizing Mr. Carone, who served as chief of staff during Eric Adams’s first year as mayor of New York.
item.dc:creator: William K. Rashbaum, Michael Rothfeld, Sally Goldenberg and Nicholas Fandos
item.category: Eric Adams Federal Corruption Case (24 CR 556)

media:content.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Frank Carone, who has been close to former mayor Eric Adams for years, opened a consulting firm after serving as Mr. Adams’s chief of staff.

item.title: Videos Show Moments in Which Agents Killed a Man in Minneapolis
item.description: Federal authorities said the slain man, Alex Pretti, had approached agents with a gun. But videos show Mr. Pretti was holding his phone, not a weapon, when they pulled him to the ground.
item.dc:creator: Devon Lum and Haley Willis

item.title: See All of Trump’s Changes to the White House So Far
item.description: In a year, the president has altered 10 spaces in the White House.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Wu, Doug Mills, Jeffrey Furticella and Nico Chilla

item.title: Edith Flanigen, Award-Winning Research Chemist, Dies at 96
item.description: She and her staff at Union Carbide created synthetic materials that improved various industrial processes, including purifying water. She also developed a way to make emeralds.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir

media:content.media:credit: Alan Zale for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Edith Flanigen in 1990. Ms. Flanigen was so widely respected that “when she walked into a room of senior management at Union Carbide, they would all stand up,” a former colleague said.

item.title: A Revelation in Paris
item.description: At Paris Fashion week, a stirring new discovery overshadowed all the runway theatrics.
item.dc:creator: Jacob Gallagher

item.title: Washington Post Tears Up Plans to Cover Winter Olympics
item.description: The abrupt change in direction came just weeks before the Olympic Games are set to begin in Italy.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mullin and Erik Wemple

media:content.media:description: The Olympic Rings and the Paralympics Agitos in Cortina d’Ampezzo, Italy, where some of the events in the Winter Olympics will be held next month.

item.title: Man Killed by Federal Agents in Minneapolis Was Holding a Phone, Not a Gun
item.description: Videos analyzed by The New York Times appear to contradict federal accounts of the shooting. The man, an I.C.U. nurse, was an American citizen with no criminal record, the city police chief said.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

media:content.media:description: Federal agents confronting protesters after fatally shooting a 37-year-old Minneapolis man.

item.title: Severe Winter Storm Brings Snow, Ice and Outages
item.description: Airlines and schools have announced extensive cancellations as a mix of snow, sleet and freezing temperatures hit regions where nearly 200 million people live.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

media:content.media:credit: William DeShazer for The New York Times
